posts.name: Doruk YÄ±ldÄ±rÄ±m
posts.cooked: Recently, our team has decided to switch from the CTRE control system to REV for the ease of use it brings. However, I realized that there are a few breaker amperage options for us to choose from. We have been running our NEOs on the 40amp channel before. Should we buy 40amp breakers and keep it that way? Also I saw a lot of people mentioning the Smart Current Limit, which we left at its default setting all this time, should we do anything about that too? Thanks!

posts.name: Tal Donde
posts.cooked:
It depends on the use case of your motor. Motors that you expect will experience a high load or are susceptible to stalling will draw a higher current. You can use this to protect your motors and motor controllers accordingly.

You can have a look at the motor datasheet to estimate a current draw under a specific motor use case.

Also keep in mind that the breaker ratings being a specific amperage donâ€™t mean that they will instantly pop once the current exceeds this number. You can have a look at the datasheet of the breaker to see how long it will take for the breaker to pop after exceeding the current.

posts.name: Calvin Hou
posts.cooked: imo for any motor I would just slap a 40A breaker on it and call it a day. You can always apply a current limit in software.

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
I recently answered several questions about breakers here, it covers the basics of breakers:

What are breakers and why are they necessary? General Forum

TLDR: Breakers are there to protect the wires. If a motor has high draw then it requires larger wires which can be protected by a larger breaker.

Albiorin:

Also I saw a lot of people mentioning the Smart Current Limit, which we left at its default setting all this time, should we do anything about that too?

Current limit are extremely effective to limit torque and protect motors, you should set them intelligently. Too low and you are leaving performance on the table. Too high and you allow for the possibility of motor damage.

I recommend you take a look at the data VEX has on motor life vs current, and for each motor consider how long it might be put under that load. For example a NEO 550 will last an entire match stalled at 20A, but if you never stall it for longer then a few seconds then a limit of 40A would give more torque: image 975Ã—664 30.4 KB

image 975Ã—664 30.4 KB

image 975Ã—664 30.4 KB

link_counts.title: What are breakers and why are they necessary?

posts.name: Aiden L
posts.cooked: Rules-wise, the size of breaker that you use scales with the wire size that you use with it. For 12AWG and larger diameters, 40A should be fine. If you start dropping to 14, 18, or 22AWG, I think you need to use smaller breakers. The exact details can be found in the manual.
